title: Plots for the TILT Project
text: goal tiltPlot provide plots TILT project.

title: Plots for the TILT Project
text: can install development version tiltPlot GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("2DegreesInvesting/tiltPlot")

title: Plots for the TILT Project
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(tiltPlot)

title: Plots for the TILT Project
text: default Sankey Plot. default function plots companies uses “equal_weight” mode.  can also choose plot without company node.  Finally, user can choose different modes plot Sankey plot financial data available.
code: financial #> # A tibble: 114 × 13 #>    bank_id amount_total company_name postcode wz    xctr_risk_category benchmark #>    <chr>          <int> <chr>           <int> <chr> <chr>              <chr>     #>  1 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     high               all       #>  2 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     high               unit      #>  3 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     medium             tilt_sec  #>  4 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     medium             unit_til… #>  5 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     low                isic_sec  #>  6 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     medium             unit_isi… #>  7 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     low                all       #>  8 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     low                unit      #>  9 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     medium             tilt_sec  #> 10 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     medium             unit_til… #> # ℹ 104 more rows #> # ℹ 6 more variables: product_name <chr>, tilt_sector <chr>, #> #   amount_of_distinct_products <int>, equal_weight_finance <dbl>, #> #   worst_case_finance <int>, best_case_finance <int> fin <- financial plot_sankey(fin) plot_sankey(fin, with_company = FALSE) plot_sankey(fin, with_company = FALSE, mode = "best_case")

title: Plots for the TILT Project
text: company level:  portfolio level:
code: financial #> # A tibble: 114 × 13 #>    bank_id amount_total company_name postcode wz    xctr_risk_category benchmark #>    <chr>          <int> <chr>           <int> <chr> <chr>              <chr>     #>  1 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     high               all       #>  2 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     high               unit      #>  3 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     medium             tilt_sec  #>  4 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     medium             unit_til… #>  5 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     low                isic_sec  #>  6 bank_b           500 peter peasa…    53773 A     medium             unit_isi… #>  7 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     low                all       #>  8 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     low                unit      #>  9 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     medium             tilt_sec  #> 10 bank_b           500 tilman          12043 D     medium             unit_til… #> # ℹ 104 more rows #> # ℹ 6 more variables: product_name <chr>, tilt_sector <chr>, #> #   amount_of_distinct_products <int>, equal_weight_finance <dbl>, #> #   worst_case_finance <int>, best_case_finance <int> fin <- financial  plot_xctr_financial(fin, "peter", mode = "worst_case") +   labs(title = "Risk distribution of all products on a company level, on a financial weight") plot_xctr_financial(fin, mode = "worst_case") +   labs(title = "Risk distribution of all products on a portfolio level, on a financial weight")

title: Plots for the TILT Project
text: plot company level:  portfolio level :
code: without_financial #> # A tibble: 58 × 5 #>    company_name  xctr_risk_category benchmark     product_name tilt_sector #>    <chr>         <chr>              <chr>         <chr>        <chr>       #>  1 peter peasant high               all           car          D           #>  2 peter peasant high               unit          car          D           #>  3 peter peasant medium             tilt_sec      car          D           #>  4 peter peasant medium             unit_tilt_sec car          D           #>  5 peter peasant low                isic_sec      car          D           #>  6 peter peasant low                unit_isic_sec car          D           #>  7 peter         high               all           banana       A           #>  8 peter         high               unit          banana       A           #>  9 peter         medium             tilt_sec      banana       A           #> 10 peter         medium             unit_tilt_sec banana       A           #> # ℹ 48 more rows no_fin <- without_financial  no_fin |>   filter(company_name == "peter") |>   plot_xctr() +   labs(title = "Risk distribution of all products on a company level") plot_xctr(no_fin) +   labs(title = "Risk distribution of all products on a portfolio level")

what: 4. Create a German map with risk categories color gradient
title: Plots for the TILT Project
code: map_region_risk(financial, "DE", benchmark = "unit_isic_sec") +   labs(title = "German map of high, medium and low propotion of the companies    that are found in one region.   © EuroGeographics for the administrative boundaries ") #> Object cached at /tmp/Rtmp2M7MqW/eurostat/sf10320163035.RData #> Reading cache file /tmp/Rtmp2M7MqW/eurostat/sf10320163035.RData #> sf at resolution 1: 10  from year  2016  read from cache file:  /tmp/Rtmp2M7MqW/eurostat/sf10320163035.RData

what: Create a map with the risk color of each region (NUTS3 granularity) — map_region_risk
title: Create a map with the risk color of each region (NUTS3 granularity) — map_region_risk
text: Create map risk color region (NUTS3 granularity)

title: Create a map with the risk color of each region (NUTS3 granularity) — map_region_risk
code: map_region_risk(   data,   country_code = c("DE"),   benchmark = c("all", "unit", "tilt_sec", "unit_tilt_sec", "isic_sec", "unit_isic_sec"),   finance_weight = c("equal_weight", "worst_case", "best_case") )

title: Create a map with the risk color of each region (NUTS3 granularity) — map_region_risk
text: data data frame like financial country_code Country code (ISO 3166 alpha-2) map plotted. benchmark mode benchmark plot. can one "", "unit" "tilt_sec", "unit_tilt_sec", "isic_sec" "unit_isic_sec". nothing chosen, "" default mode. finance_weight mode financial data plot (#TODO : fix financial columns). can one "equal_weight", "worst_case" "best_case". nothing chosen, "equal_weight" default mode.

title: Create a map with the risk color of each region (NUTS3 granularity) — map_region_risk
text: ggplot2 object representing country data plot.

title: Create a map with the risk color of each region (NUTS3 granularity) — map_region_risk
code: # Plot a German with a "unit" benchmark and equal_weight finance map_region_risk(financial, country_code = "DE", benchmark = "unit") #> Object cached at /tmp/RtmpdtDpsJ/eurostat/sf10320163035.RData #> sf at resolution 1: 10  cached at:  /tmp/RtmpdtDpsJ/eurostat/sf10320163035.RData

what: Create a sankey plot with financial data — plot_sankey
title: Create a sankey plot with financial data — plot_sankey
text: Create sankey plot financial data

title: Create a sankey plot with financial data — plot_sankey
code: plot_sankey(   data,   with_company = TRUE,   mode = c("equal_weight", "worst_case", "best_case") )

title: Create a sankey plot with financial data — plot_sankey
text: data data frame like financial. with_company Logical. TRUE, plot node company name. FALSE, plot without company name node. mode String. Several modes can chosen user : "equal_weight" means divide amount loan number products company. "worst_case" means weigh loan assume money goes highest risk product. two products associated highest risk, assume equal weights . "best_case" - similar worst-case scenario just lowest-risk category.

title: Create a sankey plot with financial data — plot_sankey
text: sankey plot class ggalluvial.

title: Create a sankey plot with financial data — plot_sankey
code: # Plot with equal weight and with company name plot_sankey(financial)   # Plot with best_case weight plot_sankey(financial, mode = "best_case")

what: Plot xctr data without financial data — plot_xctr
title: Plot xctr data without financial data — plot_xctr
text: Generate bar plots showing distribution xctr_risk_category percentages benchmark.

title: Plot xctr data without financial data — plot_xctr
code: plot_xctr(data)

text: ggplot object.

title: Plot xctr data without financial data — plot_xctr
code: plot_xctr(without_financial)

what: Plot xctr data on a company or portfolio level, with financial data — plot_xctr_financial
title: Plot xctr data on a company or portfolio level, with financial data — plot_xctr_financial
text: Plots financial data either specific company portfolio whole.

title: Plot xctr data on a company or portfolio level, with financial data — plot_xctr_financial
code: plot_xctr_financial(   data,   company_name = NULL,   mode = c("equal_weight", "worst_case", "best_case") )

title: Plot xctr data on a company or portfolio level, with financial data — plot_xctr_financial
text: data data frame like financial company_name (optional) name specific company plot financial data . NULL, function plot financial data portfolio. mode mode financial data plot. can one "equal_weight", "worst_case" "best_case".

title: Plot xctr data on a company or portfolio level, with financial data — plot_xctr_financial
text: ggplot2 object representing financial data plot.

title: Plot xctr data on a company or portfolio level, with financial data — plot_xctr_financial
code: # Example 1: Plot financial data for a specific company plot_xctr_financial(data = financial, company_name = "peter", mode = "equal_weight")   # Example 2: Plot portfolio-level financial data plot_xctr_financial(data = financial, mode = "worst_case")
